8. It costs money to bring the best teams here. Ralroad fares, food and shelter for visiting teams have to
be provided and this money comes from these season tickets. Uniforms and the various tools and implements
used in the games have to be replaced—and to keep all these angles of outdoor sports at the point of efficiency,
we must sell $15,000 worth.
9. Another point, the character of our audience is high class. A lady can be brought as a guest to any

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 10, 1922
"VALE"
This number of the NEWS-LETTER is the last to be issued under the
present Board of Control, since the editor for 1921-22 takes charge today.
It is not without a feeling of regret, in spite of the spring fever in
the air, that the present editors lay down their pens. Our administration
has lasted for almost two years, in which time the NEWS-LETTER has
succeeded in wiping out the debt and in changing from a weekly to a
semi-weekly publication. Other activities have not been idle and this
period has witnessed a remarkable development in undergraduate life.
The campus is becoming more collegiate and an "esprit de corps' is
rapidly being developed.
Among the new activities which have appeared and seem well on
the road to success are the Black and Blue Jay, the undergraduate
orchestra and the student band. The athletic management has shown
marked increase in efficiency and our teams have displayed corresponding
improvement. The Student Publicity Board, recently organized, should
do much to bring the undergraduate college before the public eye. Many
new fraternities, engineering and other social societies have made their
appearance. A home for stray Greeks is now provided by Sigma Chi
Beta; and Omicron Delta Kappa is taking an active lead in affairs on the
campus and is publishing a long needed Hopkins Song Book. A dormitory is still the most essential need of the Undergraduate Department
and the erection of this building and the new chemical laboratory at
Homewood should usher in a new era for the college.
Many of the changes which have taken place can be attributed either
directly or indirectly to the NEWS-LETTER. The Student Activities fee,
the Varsity Seal, the 0. D. K. cup, the freshman activities button and
the regulation requiring all freshmen to go out for an activity are
examples. We have also done our best to bring about a change in the
method of class elections and in the entrance requirements, and have
advocated the keeping of accurate records of each student's activity.
In all things we have endeavored to present accurately the student opinion
and to promote undergraduate life.
Our period of activity is now over, and the new Board of Control
takes up our work. We have the greatest confidence in their ability and
feel sure that their efforts will be crowned with success.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 10, 1922
"VALE"
This number of the NEWS-LETTER is the last to be issued under the
present Board of Control, since the editor for 1921-22 takes charge today.
It is not without a feeling of regret, in spite of the spring fever in
the air, that the present editors lay down their pens. Our administration
has lasted for almost two years, in which time the NEWS-LETTER has
succeeded in wiping out the debt and in changing from a weekly to a
semi-weekly publication. Other activities have not been idle and this
period has witnessed a remarkable development in undergraduate life.
The campus is becoming more collegiate and an "esprit de corps' is
rapidly being developed.
Among the new activities which have appeared and seem well on
the road to success are the Black and Blue Jay, the undergraduate
orchestra and the student band. The athletic management has shown
marked increase in efficiency and our teams have displayed corresponding
improvement. The Student Publicity Board, recently organized, should
do much to bring the undergraduate college before the public eye. Many
new fraternities, engineering and other social societies have made their
appearance. A home for stray Greeks is now provided by Sigma Chi
Beta; and Omicron Delta Kappa is taking an active lead in affairs on the
campus and is publishing a long needed Hopkins Song Book. A dormitory is still the most essential need of the Undergraduate Department
and the erection of this building and the new chemical laboratory at
Homewood should usher in a new era for the college.
Many of the changes which have taken place can be attributed either
directly or indirectly to the NEWS-LETTER. The Student Activities fee,
the Varsity Seal, the 0. D. K. cup, the freshman activities button and
the regulation requiring all freshmen to go out for an activity are
examples. We have also done our best to bring about a change in the
method of class elections and in the entrance requirements, and have
advocated the keeping of accurate records of each student's activity.
In all things we have endeavored to present accurately the student opinion
and to promote undergraduate life.
Our period of activity is now over, and the new Board of Control
takes up our work. We have the greatest confidence in their ability and
feel sure that their efforts will be crowned with success.
